channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Boris Johnson, British Foreign Secretary, Drops Dual U.S. Citizenship
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the British foreign secretary who was born in New York, gave up his American citizenship in 2016, Treasury Department records showed.
item.description: The former London mayor and “Brexit” advocate, who was born in New York, had long complained about still having to pay American taxes.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Blame Ricochets in Deaths of Rebel Army Leaders in Ukraine
item.media:description: Mikhail Tolstykh, right, a leader of the Russian-backed separatist army, in 2014 in Donetsk, Ukraine. Mr. Tolstykh was killed on Wednesday in an explosion in his office.
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.description: Ukraine and Russia have denied any role in the latest separatist death, of Mikhail Tolstykh, or in previous killings of rebel leaders far from the front lines.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Fury Rises in France Over Accusations Police Beat and Raped a Black Man
item.media:description: The remains of a car on Tuesday after it was burned the night before by protesters in Aulnay-sous-Bois, north of Paris.
item.description: Youths set cars and trash bins ablaze and vandalized buildings in suburbs around Paris, venting rage for the fourth straight day over the allegations.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Fire Tears Through Manila Slum, Leaving 15,000 Homeless
item.media:description: A resident tried to put out a fire that swept through a Manila shantytown on Tuesday night.
item.description: Dozens were injured but no one was killed, officials said, as the narrow alleyways blocked fire trucks and residents tried fighting the blaze with buckets of water.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Pope Francis Rebukes Myanmar Over Treatment of Rohingya
item.media:description: A Rohingya refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh. The United Nations estimates that about 69,000 Rohingya Muslims have fled to Bangladesh from Myanmar since October.
item.description: The pope spoke after a United Nations report found that crimes against humanity had possibly been committed against the group, a Muslim minority.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Battle to Retake Syrian City Turns Into a Geopolitical Test of the War
item.media:description: Syrian rebels backed by Turkey attacked Islamic State positions last month in Aleppo Province.
item.media:credit: Huseyin Nasir/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: A race is on to reclaim Al Bab from Islamic State extremists. Whether the rival forces ringing the city will cooperate or kill one another is unclear.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Submarine Case Is Haunting Netanyahu at a Critical Time
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, second from left, at a ceremony marking the arrival of a German-made submarine in 2016.
item.description: Even as the Israeli prime minister makes concessions to far-right rivals, accusations in a naval contracts case and two other inquiries are weakening him.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: 2nd Colombian Rebel Group Steps Up to the Table for Peace Talks
item.description: The National Liberation Army, Colombia’s second-largest rebel group, follows in the footsteps of the largest one in moving closer to ending a 52-year conflict.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Corruption Scandal Ensnares Leaders of Peru and Colombia
item.media:description: Former President Alejandro Toledo of Peru is accused of receiving $20 million in bribes from the Brazilian construction firm Odebrecht.
item.description: Alejandro Toledo, a former president of Peru, was accused of taking $20 million in bribes, and Colombian prosecutors said their leader’s campaign might have received improper donations.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE

item.title: Former Prime Minister Is Elected President of Struggling Somalia
item.media:description: Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed on Wednesday after he was elected president of Somalia.
item.description: Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed, who holds American and Somali citizenship and has worked for the New York State government, was elected by Parliament in a second round of voting.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Joyous Africans Take to the Rails, With China’s Help
item.description: A new railway line from Djibouti to Ethiopia has showcased China’s effort to extend its influence, with aid and expertise, throughout Africa.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Yemen Backtracks on Suspending U.S. Raids After Civilian Casualties
item.media:description: Graffiti in Sanaa, Yemen, denouncing strikes by United States drones.
item.description: Yemeni officials are caught between the public outrage at home over civilian deaths and fear of losing American counterterrorism assistance.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Letters From Jacqueline Kennedy to the Man She Didn’t Marry
item.media:description: Jacqueline Kennedy visiting the temples of Angkor Wat in Cambodia with David Ormsby Gore, in sunglasses, in 1967. He proposed a few months later; she said no. Her letter to him detailing why will soon be auctioned.
item.description: Newly discovered letters from Mrs. Kennedy to Lord Harlech, whose heart she broke, explain her decision to marry Aristotle Onassis.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Militants Kill 6 Red Cross Workers in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Afghans at a hospital in Mazar-i-Sharif on Wednesday unloaded the coffin of an employee of the International Committee of the Red Cross who was killed by gunmen in Jowzjan Province.
item.description: Officials said they believed the ambush, in Jowzjan Province, was led by Islamic State loyalists, who have been active in the area recently.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Did Kuwait Copy Trump’s Travel Ban? Not Quite
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with county sheriffs at the White House on Tuesday. On Facebook, Mr. Trump praised news that Kuwait imposed its own visa ban on certain Muslim-majority countries, apparently following his lead. It turned out the ban was actually from 2011.
item.description: Many news sites issued corrections for an erroneous story about a Kuwaiti visa ban on mostly Muslim countries. President Trump has yet to do so.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Istanbul Journal: In Istanbul, Surprise That Trump Towers Complex Is Linked to Trump
item.media:description: Trump Towers Istanbul, among the tallest buildings in one of the world’s largest Muslim cities, last year. Many of the people there on a recent evening were unaware that it was connected to President Trump.
item.media:credit: Monique Jaques for The New York Times
item.description: Many diners, shoppers and store owners did not understand the president’s connection to the complex, and some were unhappy to find it out.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Aleksei Navalny, Viable Putin Rival, Is Barred From a Presidential Run
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, left, at a court hearing on Wednesday in Kirov, Russia.
item.description: A Russian court convicted Mr. Navalny on fraud charges, again, in an effort to deny him a national platform to challenge President Vladimir V. Putin’s authority.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Southwestern Pakistan Rattled by Magnitude 6.4 Earthquake
item.description: A Pakistani official says a strong, magnitude 6.4 earthquake has struck the country's remote southwest and that there are reports of damages to houses but no casualties.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: German Automakers Step Up to Silicon Valley Challenge
item.media:description: Ole Harms on the last day in his old office in Wolfsburg, Germany, in December. Mr. Harms, chief executive at MOIA, a Volkswagen-backed ride-hailing start-up, moved to Berlin, which has a growing tech scene.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: BMW, Daimler and Volkswagen are striving with increasing urgency to ride the digital wave sweeping the industry, before it rolls over them.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and MARK SCOTT

item.title: Many Apply, Few Qualify: Canada Rejects Indian Status for Thousands
item.description: Canada has rejected more than 72,000 applications from people seeking Indian status, the latest turn in a chaotic process to decide who in Newfoundland qualifies as a Native Canadian.
item.dc:creator: CRAIG S. SMITH

item.title: Tzvetan Todorov, Literary Theorist and Historian of Evil, Dies at 77
item.media:description: Tzvetan Todorov during an interview at the Washington Square Hotel in New York in April 2001.
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times
item.description: A prolific Bulgarian-French scholar, Mr. Todorov published widely on the moral consequences of colonialism, racism and genocide.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Yemen Withdraws Permission for U.S. Antiterror Ground Missions
item.media:description: Women walk past graffiti denouncing strikes by U.S. drones, in Sanaa, Yemen.
item.description: The suspension of commando operations in Yemen is a setback for President Trump, who says he wants to take a more aggressive approach against Islamic militants.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: White House Weighs Terrorist Designation for Muslim Brotherhood
item.media:description: Egyptians prayed in celebration of the election of a Muslim Brotherhood member, Mohamed Morsi, to the presidency in 2012.
item.description: The Brotherhood, with millions of followers, is the oldest Islamist group in the Middle East, and designating it as a terrorist group would roil the region.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: ‘Irrational’ Coal Plants May Hamper China’s Climate Change Efforts
item.media:description: The China Kingho Energy Group’s coal-to-gas plant in Chuluqay, Xinjiang, China, in 2014.
item.description: Plants that convert coal to gas, an expensive and environmentally detrimental process, may thwart China’s aim to be a global leader on limiting climate change.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Our Articles on the Attacks Trump Says the Media Didn’t Cover
item.media:description: Belgians gathered on March 23, 2016, to pay their respects in front of the old Brussels stock exchange after a terrorist attack the day before killed dozens and wounded hundreds.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: Here is the Trump administration’s list of what it calls underreported terrorist attacks. The Times covered most of the attacks cited, many with multiple articles.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER and KITTY BENNETT

item.title: Duterte Gives ‘Rotten’ Officers Choice: Go to Terrorist Hotbed or Go Home
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines assailed police officers during a live broadcast on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Robinson Ninal/Presidential Photographers Division, via Associated Press
item.description: The ultimatum, broadcast on national television, was presented to over 200 police officers accused of a litany of criminal and professional misdeeds.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Woman Was Thrown Into Ocean, Autopsy Says, in Murder That Shook Iceland
item.media:description: A public memorial in Reykjavik last month for Birna Brjansdottir, who was killed in January. Murders are exceedingly rare in Iceland.
item.description: A leaked autopsy report in the rare killing says that Birna Brjansdottir was alive when she was thrown, but it was not clear if the killer knew that or if she was conscious.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and EGILL BJARNASON

item.title: Trump Plan to Visit U.K. Sets Off Political Dispute
item.media:description: John Bercow, the speaker of the British House of Commons, says he opposes the possibility that President Trump might be asked to address Parliament.
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.description: The speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow, said Mr. Trump should not address Parliament, but other Conservative lawmakers disagreed.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy Ordered to Stand Trial Over Campaign Finances
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy at a presidential campaign rally in Paris in 2012.
item.description: The former president, accused of spending more than the legal limit on his 2012 campaign, was expected to appeal.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Bombing Near Afghan Supreme Court in Kabul Kills and Wounds Dozens
item.media:description: Security forces near the site of a suicide blast outside the Supreme Court building in Kabul, Afghanistan, on Tuesday.
item.description: Witnesses said a suicide bomber walked up to the entrance of the court as workers were leaving and set off his explosives. No one has claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Sinosphere: Donald Trump’s Tweets About a Judge Find a Critic in an Unlikely Place: China
item.media:description: A protest outside the Supreme Court in Washington last month against President Trump’s executive order banning travel to the United States from seven majority-Muslim countries.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: He Fan of the Supreme People’s Court published a scathing blog post saying the president had breached the principle of an independent judiciary.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Thanks Trump for Showing America’s ‘True Face’
item.description: Mr. Trump’s behavior has proved “what we have been saying for more than 30 years,” Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Sinosphere: Debate Flares Over China’s Inclusion at Vatican Organ Trafficking Meeting
item.media:description: Dr. Huang Jiefu, co-chairman of the National Organ Donation and Transplantation Committee of China, at a meeting on organ trafficking at the Vatican on Tuesday.
item.description: A group of ethicists have expressed concern that China will use the meeting to convince the world that it no longer harvests organs from prisoners.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Hong Kong Journal: Using Stealth, and Drones, to Document a Fading Hong Kong
item.media:description: A member of HK Urbex who goes by the alias T.O.a.D. looking down at the State Theater, built in 1952, in the North Point section of Hong Kong. The group is building a video archive of the city’s colonial-era architecture.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: “It’s about forcing us to confront the aesthetic of loss,” a professor says of a film oeuvre that captures colonial-era buildings before they are razed.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Shouldn’t Israel Care About Anti-Semitism?
item.media:description: Lighting candles on International Holocaust Remembrance Day last month at the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.
item.description: The Israeli government has to balance its devotion to defending all Jews and its foreign relations.
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: President Duterte Is Repeating My Mistakes
item.media:description: In Quezon City, Philippines, inmates sleep on a basketball court at Quezon City Jail, one of the country’s most congested jails on Oct. 19, 2016.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: When I was president of Colombia, I learned that a “war on drugs’’ is unwinnable.
item.dc:creator: CÉSAR GAVIRIA

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Queen for a Free Trade Deal
item.media:description: A neighborhood in Sunderland, England, where Brexit was heavily favored.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Theresa May’s Brexit-buffeted Britain offers a bridge to Trump, but Europe mulls a rampart.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
